awd_abstract_narration:
Industry leaders have identified information technology as a target area for economic growth and development in Miami-Dade County. One of the most in-demand skills for information technology (IT) technicians is enterprise cloud computing.  However, higher education has not yet developed comprehensive curricula, educational resources, and information technology training programs that lead to industry certification in cloud computing.  To meet this need and serve as a model for other community colleges, this project at Miami Dade College InterAmerican Campus aims to develop and implement a new educational pathway in cloud computing. The student body at Miami Date College InterAmerican Campus includes a large, predominantly low-income, minority student population.  As a result, the project has the potential to increase the number of certified cloud computing technicians from underrepresented minority groups to meet local and national workforce needs. 

The project objectives include: (1) Development and implementation of a professional development program that will train 15 MDC technology faculty members to teach cloud computing courses utilizing project-based learning methodology; (2) Creation of an academic pathway that will align a college credit certificate in Enterprise Cloud Computing to associate and baccalaureate degrees in information systems technology; (3) Recruitment, retention, and graduation of approximately 25 students each academic year in the newly developed Enterprise Cloud Computing program; (4) Development of a K-16 pipeline by offering a Cloud 101 summer boot camp for 40 high school students from traditionally underrepresented populations.  In addition to curriculum development, the project also aims to advance knowledge about student success and degree attainment in technology fields and to generate a deeper understanding of factors that lead to improved retention of (STEM) students at Hispanic-serving institutions. This information can benefit other institutions that are committed to advancing underrepresented student success in technology disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The DECCI (Dade Enterprise Cloud Computing Initiative) project, in collaboration with Amazon Web Services (AWS), focused on creating a cloud computing pathway at Miami Dade College (MDC) to increase the number of certified cloud computing technicians from underrepresented minorities to meet workforce needs in this emerging high-demand field. 

The NSF ATE DECCI project concluded with the following outcomes impacting computing/IT education and workforce:  

  • Partnered with local and national cloud companies to develop innovative cloud curriculum, train MDC faculty, educate and certify students, and secure student employment. MDC and AWS received the 2022 AACC's Outstanding College/Corporate Partnership Award for their work together in developing cloud computing degrees, which became frameworks for other higher education institutions to use as a baseline or to replicate.
  • Launched cutting-edge Cloud Computing Center to house the only College Credit Certificate and Associate of Science degrees in Enterprise Cloud Computing in the State of Florida, and host accelerated training programs, summer camps, forums, speakers, and events. The Center, funded by Perkins IV in 2019, serves as a hub where technology leaders, industry experts and students can engage and collaborate to use core design patterns and infrastructure expertise to implement solutions to deploy and maintain workloads and applications.
  • Implemented a collective impact approach to broaden participation and improve diversity in cloud computing-related fields. The new college credit certificate program in Enterprise Cloud Computing launched in Fall 2019 and had more than 150 enrolled students. Ninety percent (90%) of the completers continued their studies with (associate and/or bachelor's) degrees in cybersecurity, data analytics, or information technology.
  • Cloud transitioning of courseware expanded non-traditional student access to materials and IT infrastructure environments generally not available in standard classroom settings.
  • Demand for instructional resources influenced traditional corporate education and certification companies to create higher education focused access, specifically A Cloud Guru.
  • Professional Development (PD) enhanced the ways in which faculty teach their classes. Faculty reported that the teaching styles they experienced in their PD, the mix of online and face to face allowed them to work as professionals, meet their current objectives, and be flexible enough to add in the studies, which really gave them some ideas about how to enhance and move towards a blended style of class. Thirty-seven (37) certifications were earned by 12 faculty during the grant period. MDC has the most certified solutions architect educators in the country.
  • COVID-19 impacted classroom delivery significantly. The online component of the PD, introduction of advanced resources for computation in cloud, all converged to make transitioning cloud and other technology classes to a fully online environment significantly easier than it would have been using traditional instruction strategies.
  • Produced some of the first, and youngest, certified cloud practitioners and solutions architects in the country. Ninety-seven (97) students participated in the Cloud 101 bootcamp. The summer camp received the 2019 Inspiring Program in STEM Award from Insight Into Diversity. 
  • Created a stronger community among MDC faculty and increased their pride in the program.
  • Supported the acquisition of more advanced credentials in multiple cloud fields from AWS and other cloud providers.
  • Allowed for introduction of cloud concepts in non-cloud courses. Entry level programming, database design and networking courses all have access to cloud-based labs moving away from physical infrastructure generally needed to support these classes. Students in all cloud-related courses earned 397 certifications during the grant period. 
  • Expressed an interest in engaging in more efforts to increase MDC's international profile in cloud computing by contributing to future research.
  • Success of DECCI interaction with high school students encouraged AWS to expand their program nationally to the K-12 environment.
  • Feedback from DECCI impacted the method and deliverables from AWS reflecting lessons learned over the course of the grant. This included materials, courses, access, and systems support.

While the findings of this project are for entry-level cloud literacy, they provide some insight into the potential to engage more minority students in computing/IT education and workforce; and thus, positively influence the number of students and professionals of color who succeed in skilling, upskilling and reskilling in STEM education, workforce and beyond. DECCI also encouraged the next level of cloud instruction through the application and acquisition of the NSF ATE Emerging Cloud Hub Opportunities (ECHO) grant (Award# 2055344) to address the upskilling possibilities.

DECCI also provided proof of  the need to incorporate cloud and related technical skills as early in the curriculum as possible. The use of industry standard cloud tools in earlier, non-cloud specific classes, enhances instruction and better prepares students for future classes and career opportunities.


Last Modified: 10/21/2022
Modified by: Elodie V Billionniere

por.por_txt_cntn:
The DECCI (Dade Enterprise Cloud Computing Initiative) project, in collaboration with Amazon Web Services (AWS), focused on creating a cloud computing pathway at Miami Dade College (MDC) to increase the number of certified cloud computing technicians from underrepresented minorities to meet workforce needs in this emerging high-demand field. 

The NSF ATE DECCI project concluded with the following outcomes impacting computing/IT education and workforce:  

Partnered with local and national cloud companies to develop innovative cloud curriculum, train MDC faculty, educate and certify students, and secure student employment. MDC and AWS received the 2022 AACC's Outstanding College/Corporate Partnership Award for their work together in developing cloud computing degrees, which became frameworks for other higher education institutions to use as a baseline or to replicate.
Launched cutting-edge Cloud Computing Center to house the only College Credit Certificate and Associate of Science degrees in Enterprise Cloud Computing in the State of Florida, and host accelerated training programs, summer camps, forums, speakers, and events. The Center, funded by Perkins IV in 2019, serves as a hub where technology leaders, industry experts and students can engage and collaborate to use core design patterns and infrastructure expertise to implement solutions to deploy and maintain workloads and applications.
Implemented a collective impact approach to broaden participation and improve diversity in cloud computing-related fields. The new college credit certificate program in Enterprise Cloud Computing launched in Fall 2019 and had more than 150 enrolled students. Ninety percent (90%) of the completers continued their studies with (associate and/or bachelor's) degrees in cybersecurity, data analytics, or information technology.
Cloud transitioning of courseware expanded non-traditional student access to materials and IT infrastructure environments generally not available in standard classroom settings.
Demand for instructional resources influenced traditional corporate education and certification companies to create higher education focused access, specifically A Cloud Guru.
Professional Development (PD) enhanced the ways in which faculty teach their classes. Faculty reported that the teaching styles they experienced in their PD, the mix of online and face to face allowed them to work as professionals, meet their current objectives, and be flexible enough to add in the studies, which really gave them some ideas about how to enhance and move towards a blended style of class. Thirty-seven (37) certifications were earned by 12 faculty during the grant period. MDC has the most certified solutions architect educators in the country.
COVID-19 impacted classroom delivery significantly. The online component of the PD, introduction of advanced resources for computation in cloud, all converged to make transitioning cloud and other technology classes to a fully online environment significantly easier than it would have been using traditional instruction strategies.
Produced some of the first, and youngest, certified cloud practitioners and solutions architects in the country. Ninety-seven (97) students participated in the Cloud 101 bootcamp. The summer camp received the 2019 Inspiring Program in STEM Award from Insight Into Diversity. 
Created a stronger community among MDC faculty and increased their pride in the program.
Supported the acquisition of more advanced credentials in multiple cloud fields from AWS and other cloud providers.
Allowed for introduction of cloud concepts in non-cloud courses. Entry level programming, database design and networking courses all have access to cloud-based labs moving away from physical infrastructure generally needed to support these classes. Students in all cloud-related courses earned 397 certifications during the grant period. 
Expressed an interest in engaging in more efforts to increase MDC's international profile in cloud computing by contributing to future research.
Success of DECCI interaction with high school students encouraged AWS to expand their program nationally to the K-12 environment.
Feedback from DECCI impacted the method and deliverables from AWS reflecting lessons learned over the course of the grant. This included materials, courses, access, and systems support.


While the findings of this project are for entry-level cloud literacy, they provide some insight into the potential to engage more minority students in computing/IT education and workforce; and thus, positively influence the number of students and professionals of color who succeed in skilling, upskilling and reskilling in STEM education, workforce and beyond. DECCI also encouraged the next level of cloud instruction through the application and acquisition of the NSF ATE Emerging Cloud Hub Opportunities (ECHO) grant (Award# 2055344) to address the upskilling possibilities.

DECCI also provided proof of  the need to incorporate cloud and related technical skills as early in the curriculum as possible. The use of industry standard cloud tools in earlier, non-cloud specific classes, enhances instruction and better prepares students for future classes and career opportunities.
